title: Paris-Nice 2023: Route, how to watch, start list including Pogačar vs Vingegaard
content:
Cyclist
Paris-Nice 2023: Route, how to watch, start list including Pogačar vs Vingegaard

Paris-Nice, nicknamed the Race to the Sun, is one of the biggest one-week stage races on the men’s WorldTour calendar with Tour de France hopefuls using it to test early season shape or just get into the swing on things once more.

It is a race formerly dominated by Sean Kelly, who claimed seven overall wins and a bunch more stages throughout his career, and more recently was a hunting ground for the 2010s Team Sky line-ups with wins for Bradley Wiggins, Richie Porte, Geraint Thomas, Sergio Henao and Egan Bernal.

2023 is set to be the most hotly contested Paris-Nice for years with Tour de France rivals Tadej Pogačar and Jonas Vingegaard lining up against each other for the first time since July.

This edition, the 81st, will see riders head out from La Verrière, just south-west of Paris, on Sunday 5th March and finish on Sunday 12th March in Nice itself, starting and finishing on the beach.

Paris-Nice 2023: Key information

Date: 5th March-12th March 2023
Start: La Verrière
Finish: Nice
Stages: Eight, including one team time-trial
UK television coverage: ITV4 (highlights), Eurosport, GCN+, Discovery+
Most wins: Sean Kelly, seven
2022 winner: Primož Roglič (Jumbo-Visma)

Related Posts

Best places to cycle in the French Alps

Tour de France Femmes 2023: Full 956km route announced

Men’s Tour de France 2023: 3,404km route announced

Paris-Nice 2023 route

The 2023 race begins just west of Paris at La Varrière with a lumpy loop that the riders take on twice, finishing back in La Varrière. Stage 2 starts a little further north in Bazainville for a flat stage to Fontainebleau.

Stage 3 is something a little different, a 32.2km team time-trial around Dampierre-en-Burly. In this flat TTT riders will be given their actual finishing times to count for the general classification rather than the team sharing the same time. That means overall contenders may end up breaking away from their teammates should they have the energy or if the team is struggling.

Stage 4 should shake things up properly, while the peloton takes a mainly flat way out from Saint-Amand-Montrond, the final run-in to La Loge des Gardes is a 6.7km Category 1 climb with an average gradient of 7.1%.

There’s another sprinters’ day on Stage 5 from Saint-Symphorien to Saint-Paul-Trois-Châteaux before the action really hots up on Stage 6 when the race arrives on the Côte d’Azur, with a profile resembling a classic with several short climbs along the way from Tourves to La Colle-sur-Loup that ramp up to 15%, 17%, 20%, 19% and 12%.

Stages 7 and 8 both start in Nice, making it more of an orbit than a race to the sun, with Stage 7 features two Category 1 climbs including the summit finish up the 15.7km, 7.1% average Col de la Couillole before Stage 8 packs in five shorter, but not easy, climbs, including the Col d’Èze, before finishing back on the Promenade des Anglais.

Paris-Nice 2023: stage-by-stage

Stage 1: Sunday 5th March, La Verrière – La Verrière, 169.5km

An intermediate 6km from the finish is… interesting, so it’s likely going to be for those after cheeky bonus seconds and the first yellow jersey rather than sprinters who’ll be contesting the finale.

Stage 2: Monday 6th March, Bazainville – Fontainebleau, 164km

For Stage 2, the intermediate sprint is 13km from the finish, which could be just far enough from the line to get sprinters involved but probably not. Expect smaller teams contesting these for the sponsors.

Stage 3: Tuesday 7th March, Dampierre-en-Burly – Dampierre-en-Burly, 32.2km, TTT

The first real shake-up will happen here and it’s Jumbo-Visma and UAE Team Emirates to keep an eye on, the former being stacked with time-trial specialists, the latter being stacked with Tadej Pogačar.

Stage 4: Wednesday 8th March, Saint-Amand-Montrond – La Loge des Gardes, 165km

It’s not about what’s waiting on the other side, it’s about how fast you get there. Expect fireworks, either from the two expected protagonists or the outsiders who need to try and get as much time as possible out of them – largely Dani Martínez, David Gaudu, Jack Haig, Max Schachmann, Neilson Powless, Romain Bardet and Simon Yates. Wow, stacked race, huh?

Stage 5: Thursday 9th March, Saint-Symphorien-sur-Coise – Saint-Paul-Trois-Châteaux, 212.5km

Not sure why the organisers have front-loaded this stage with climbs but it is what it is. The final kicker may tempt sprinters’ teams to try and put the pressure on the bigger lads (ie. Groupama-FDJ’s Arnaud Démare, given we know the other Arnaud, Lotto-Dstny’s De Lie, is no slouch from Opening Weekend.)

Stage 6: Friday 10th March, Tourves – La Colle-sur-Loup, 197.5km

Chaos, yes. Although the longest climb is just over 5km, look at those gradients. Expect Simon Yates to attack.

Stage 7: Saturday 11th March, Nice – Col de la Couillole, 143km

You’d think there’ll still be attacks but the gradient of Col de la Couillole is very consistent, barely going above 8% or dropping below 6%, so getting into a rhythm should be easy enough for strugglers. Breakaway win incoming.

Stage 8: Sunday 12th March, Nice – Nice, 117.5km

There’s almost guaranteed to be a small gap coming into the finale, so those occupying, or sitting close to, the podium spots will have to attack.

Paris-Nice 2023: live TV and streaming guide

As per every WorldTour race, Paris-Nice will be broadcast live on Eurosport and available to stream live on GCN+ and Discovery+ (all with the same coverage, times below).

GCN+ costs £6.99 paid monthly, or £39.99 per year and Discovery+ costs £6.99 per month or £59.99 per year for sports and entertainment (for fans of shows like 90 Day Fiancé and Ghost Adventures).

Streaming coverage via GCN+ will be available in Europe and the Asia-Pacific, not including China, Japan and New Zealand, double-check territory restrictions to avoid disappointment.

In the United States there’s live coverage of every stage on Peacock, in Canada you’ll find it on FloBikes, and in New Zealand it’s on Sky.

There will also be coverage of the race on free-to-air television in the UK with ITV4 having highlights every evening at 6pm for Stage 1 and 7pm thereafter with its usual Tour de France crew.
